title: 109_hr1234
content: The "Corporate Accountability Tax Gap Act of 2005" allows for the availability of certain tax information of publicly traded corporations. The "Corporate Accountability Tax Gap Act of 2005" requires specified corporations to electronically file and make public certain tax information annually. The "Corporate Accountability Tax Gap Act of 2005" mandates corporations to disclose various tax-related information annually, including net corporate income tax, Federal income tax expense, taxable income, adjusted book income, and specific differences between taxable income and adjusted book income. The "Corporate Accountability Tax Gap Act of 2005" requires corporations to disclose tax-related information annually, including differences between taxable income and adjusted book income due to specific transactions and additional information determined by the Secretary for enforcement purposes. The "Corporate Accountability Tax Gap Act of 2005" mandates corporations to disclose tax-related information annually, including details on abusive tax avoidance schemes. The Secretary will provide electronic access to this information through a search using specific criteria for specified corporations. The term 'specified corporation' includes corporations required to register under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and domestic corporations in an affiliated group. For consolidated returns, 'specified corporation' refers to the group, not individual members. 'Net corporate income tax' is defined as the total regular tax liability and tax. The term 'adjusted book income' refers to book income reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission without certain deductions. The amendment applies to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. STUDY OF TAX SHELTER ACTIVITY. The Secretary of the Treasury will conduct a study on recent corporate tax shelter activity, including information from the tax shelter amnesty and Enron tax returns. A report with recommendations will be submitted to the Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee within a year. The Secretary of the Treasury will submit a report to Congress containing recommendations on corporate tax shelter activity, including disclosing additional information from tax returns and actions taken to implement recommendations.
